titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Williams Family Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 06:16

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Williams Family Papers consists of correspondence, writings, documents, and financial records kept by descendants of William Williams who lived in and near Wethersfield, Connecticut, in the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. The papers are those of Elisha Williams, his second wife Elizabeth Scott Williams Smith, and his nephew Ezekiel Williams, merchant and sheriff of Hartford County. The correspondence is with family members and associates; the writings consist of sermons and essays by family members; documents are primarily related to the settlement of Elizabeth Smith's estate in the United States and England. Other papers include an engraved circular letter from London publisher James Rivington advertising a new edition of a work by Philip Doddridge.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Francis Parsons (Yale BA 1893, LLB 1897, MA (Hon) 1925), 1937. Other additions are noted at the folder level.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Williams Family Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Williams Family Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection includes materials previously identified by the following call number: Uncat MS Vault 12:1

bioghist.head: Williams Family of Connecticut and Massachusetts
bioghist.p: The papers in this collection were largely donated by Francis Parsons of Hartford, Connecticut, and document his ancestors from five generations above him, all descendants of Robert Williams (1608-1693) and his wife Elizabeth Stalham (1595-1674), who emigrated from England to Roxbury, Massachusetts, in the seventeenth century. Their son Isaac Williams (1638-1709) had a son William Williams (1665-1741), and it is the two sons of William Williams, Elisha (1694-1755) and Solomon (1701-1776), and their descendants, whose papers are present here. These families were prominent citizens and religious leaders in and around Wethersfield, a town south of Hartford. Much of the information about the family was taken from The Ancestors and Descendants of Ezekiel Williams of Wethersfield, 1608-1907 , by Mary Dyer Williams McLean (Privately printed, 1907). The principals in the papers are the following family members:

Elisha Williams (1694-1755), fourth child born to William Williams and his first wife Elizabeth Cotton Williams (1665–1698), was a Congregational minister, legislator, militia soldier, jurist, and the fourth rector of Yale College (1726-1739). He married twice, first in 1714 to Eunice Chester (died 1750), with whom he had six children, and second to Elizabeth Scott in 1751.

Elizabeth Scott Williams Smith (1708-1776) was the daughter of Thomas Scott (1680-1746), independent minister at Norwich, England. A poet and hymnist, she married Elisha Williams in 1751 and moved with him to Connecticut. In 1761 she married a prominent New York jurist, William Smith (1697-1769) and lived in New York City. After his death she returned to Wethersfield to reside at the home of Ezekiel Williams, the nephew of her first husband, until her death there on June 13, 1776.

Ezekiel Williams (1729-1818), son of Reverend Solomon Williams (1701-1776) and Mary Porter Williams (1703-1787), was a merchant in Wethersfield and sheriff of Hartford County from 1767 to 1789. He was married to Prudence Stoddard (1734-1822), with whom he had eleven children.

Francis Parsons (1871-1937), the donor of the papers, was the son of John Caldwell Parsons (1832-1898) and Mary McClellan (1844-1871). He was a banker, lawyer, and author in Hartford. and the great-great-grandson of Ezekiel Williams (1729-1818).

bioghist.head: Williams Family Tree
bioghist.p: Family members appearing in the papers are underlined.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Williams Family Papers consists of correspondence, documents, and financial records kept by descendants of William Williams who lived in and near Wethersfield, Connecticut, in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. The papers include those of Elisha Williams, his second wife Elizabeth Scott Williams Smith, and his nephew Ezekiel Williams, merchant and sheriff of Hartford County.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Elisha Williams Papers, 1711-1759. II. Elizabeth Scott Williams Smith Papers, 1735-1775. III. Ezekiel Williams Papers, 1751-1812. IV. Other Papers, 1724-1930.

controlaccess.subject: Clergy -- Connecticut
Women -- Connecticut
controlaccess.geogname: United States -- History -- Colonial period, ca. 1600-1775

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into four subseries: Incoming Letters, Outgoing Letters, Other Letters, Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains letters to and from Elisha Williams, notably twenty-six letters from Williams to his cousin Stephen Williams (1693-1782), while the latter was a student at Harvard College and afterward a resident at Hadley, Massachusetts; Stephen was the son of Reverend John Williams of Deerfield, Massachusetts, and was held captive by the Abenakis Indians in Canada for more than a year as a child. Also present are several sermons written by Elisha Williams.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Letters of 1711-1714 gift of Lemuel Welles, 1939; letter of 1724 gift of Anson P. Stokes, 1937.

did.unittitle: William Williams (1665-1741) to his grandsons Elisha, Solomon, and Eliphalet Williams
Deed for sale of land in Wethersfield from Nathaniel Burnham to Elisha Williams (1717-1784)
Drafts of letters, notes about army problems, draft of codicil to will (4 pages)
Essay, "The Doctrine of the Publick Covenant between God and his People"
Report of sermons preached in New Haven, 1729-1730

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Given to Alexander Joseph Sessions (Yale BA 1831, MA 1845) by John Stoddard Williams (Yale 1827) and then to Benjamin Osgood Peirce; gift of Isabella Landreth Peirce, 1922.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into four subseries: Incoming Letters, Outgoing Letters, Third-party Letters, and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains correspondence and other papers of Elizabeth Scott Williams Smith. The correspondence is primarily incoming from both the Scotts, her family in England, and the Williams family in Connecticut, the brothers and other relations of her first husband Elisha Williams. Notable are fourteen letters from her brother-in-law Rev. Solomon Williams, and four from her brother Thomas Scott, poet, hymnist, and minister at Ipswich; third-party correspondence includes a letter from Smith's father Thomas Scott to another Nonconformist preacher, Rev. Philip Doddridge (1702-1751) of Northampton, England. Also present are three of Smith's autograph manuscript poems.
Papers related to the settlement of Elizabeth Smith's estates in England and the United States are filed in Series III.

odd.head: General
odd.p: 19th-century manuscript copy of two letters dated 1750 and 1755.

did.unittitle: Business papers, including notes, bills, agreements

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized into four subseries: Incoming Letters, Outgoing Letters, Third-party Letters, and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains correspondence and other material related to Ezekiel Williams's family and his career as sheriff of Hartford County. Also present are some papers of his son Thomas Scott Williams (1777-1861), including letters from Williams to Thomas when he was a student at Yale College, and two of his school essays.

Notable in this series are three files documenting the estate of William's uncle's second wife, Elizabeth Scott Williams Smith (see Series II), which include her wills, correspondence related to bequests, and financial records for settling the estate in England and the United States.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Governess for Ezekiel Williams's children; includes three proposed epitaphs for her tombstone, one in the hand of Ezekiel Williams.

odd.head: General
odd.p: With undated autograph note at bottom by Mary D. McLean.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes Williams' autograph manuscript diary annotations.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Scott Williams Smith estate papers

odd.head: General
odd.p: Ezekiel Williams served as executor for his aunt's estate; the files contain her autograph will, manuscript copies of and a codicil to the will, an excerpt from William Smith's will, correspondence, invoices, and receipts.

did.unittitle: Legal and other documents related to personal and professional business

odd.p: Related to sale of land to Ezekiel Williams.

did.unittitle: Thomas Scott Williams essays on Homer and Milton

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into four subseries: Documents, Letters by Others, Writings by Others, Francis Parsons Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains papers that could not be directly attached to the people in Series I-III, but were found with the collection, including an engraved circular letter from James Rivington & Co. dated 1759. The fourth subseries, Francis Parsons Papers, contains letters to the donor of the collection regarding the family and their papers.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes typed transcripts of her published obituary (1776), a letter from her to Eliphalet Williams (1765), and photographs of a mirror and portrait she owned.
